para.text: A cosmetology program in a public school that possesses a school permit issued by the State Board of Cosmetologists, that was valid as of June 30, 1991, shall be considered an approved cosmetology program by the State Department of Education.

To obtain approval for a cosmetology program after June 30, 1991, a local school system shall apply to the State Department of Education on a form provided by the Department. The proposal for approval of a cosmetology program shall meet all the requirements in Regulations .02—.07 of this chapter.

section.heading: Program Completer Requirements for Cosmetology Operator.

para.text: A program of instruction for cosmetology operator shall require a minimum of 1,500 locally determined clock hours of instruction of which:
500 hours shall be theory; and
1,000 hours shall be demonstration and practical application.
The program shall include instruction in each of the following topics with hours as determined by the local school system:
Careers in cosmetology;
Personal development;
Bacteriology, sterilization, and sanitation;
Fundamentals of rinsing and conditioning;
Fundamentals of fingerwaving and hairstyling;
Fundamentals of scalp massage and scalp care services;
Care and styling of artificial hair;
Fundamentals and techniques of hair cutting;
Fundamentals and techniques of chemical reformation;
Fundamentals and techniques of thermal pressing and curling;
Fundamentals and techniques of hair coloring;
Diseases and disorders of the skin, scalp, nails, and hair;
Facial massage, skin care, and makeup applications;
Fundamentals of hair care services;
Superfluous hair;
Basic manicuring and pedicuring;
Anatomy in beauty culture;
Chemistry for cosmetologists;
Histology;
Electricity and the cosmetologist;
Job interviews;
Beauty salon management; and
State laws and regulations.
Related Instruction.

Related instruction, not to exceed 300 hours, may apply toward the 1,500-hour requirement when the cosmetology teacher approves hours for documented student participation in any of the following activities:
Organizational activities of the Skills USA which are directly related to the subject of cosmetology;
School-sponsored field trips planned for in the cosmetology curriculum; and

Work-study employment, after successful completion of 1,000 hours of cosmetology operator instruction, which is supervised by a senior cosmetologist and conducted under a work-based learning agreement with the school.

The supervisor shall report on all matters concerning the student's progress in work-study employment as described in §C(1)(c) of this regulation to the work-study coordinator, or if none is assigned, to the school's cosmetology teacher.
The Cosmetology teacher may certify the student's eligibility for admission to the State licensing examination upon:
Demonstrated competency upon the completion of the required minimum number of hours in the program; and
Certification of successful evaluation of the student's work by the cosmetology teacher.
The program of instruction for nail technician shall require a minimum of 250 locally determined clock hours of instruction in theory, demonstration, and practical application.
The program shall include instruction in each of the following topics with hours as determined by the local school system:
Career opportunities;
Personal development;
Bacteriology, sterilization, and sanitation;
Structure of the nail;
Disorders and diseases of the nail;
Implements, equipment, and supplies;
Manicuring and pedicuring procedures and techniques;
Massaging techniques;
Artificial application procedures;
Wrapping procedures and techniques;
Corrections and repairs;
Anatomy and physiology for the nail technician;
Basic chemistry for the nail technician;
Hazardous chemicals and beauty products;
Electricity;
First aid; and
State laws and regulations.
The cosmetology teacher may certify the student's eligibility for admission to the State licensing examination upon:
Demonstrated competency upon completion of the required minimum number of hours in the program; and
Certification of successful evaluation of the student's work by the cosmetology teacher.

section.heading: Work Kit.
section.text: Each student shall have a work kit consisting of equipment and supplies, as determined by the teacher, needed to participate in the program. The work kit may be purchased from the school or any salon supplier in the marketplace.

para.text: An enrollment record for each student shall be maintained as a permanent record by the school administrator of the building in which the cosmetology program is housed.
The student record shall:
Be updated on a quarterly basis with the grade earned by the student;
Be updated on a semester basis with the documented instructional hours earned during the student's active participation in the program;
Support the student's eligibility for admission to the State licensing examination; and
Be used to comply with the testing vendor’s process for certifying student training and verifying student experience.
A cosmetology teacher shall possess a senior cosmetology license and shall meet the teacher certification requirements in COMAR 13A.12.02.15.
A cosmetology teacher may not instruct more than 25 students at any one time.

section.heading: Sanitation.
section.text: A cosmetology program shall comply with the sanitation requirements established by the State Board of Cosmetologists in COMAR 09.22.03.

section.heading: Denial, Suspension, and Revocation of Approval.

para.text: Grounds. The State Board of Education may deny, suspend, or revoke approval of a cosmetology program if the program:
Fails to meet the standards established in Regulations .02—.07 of this chapter;
Is cited by the State Board of Cosmetologists, after a hearing, for one or more sanitation violations that are a direct hazard to a client's health or safety;
Fails to pay a fine imposed by the State Board of Cosmetologists, after a hearing for a sanitation violation, within 30 days; or
Permits a student to practice cosmetology in violation of Business Occupations and Professions Article, §§5-302 and 5-303, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Decision.

The Assistant State Superintendent for the Division of Career and College Readiness shall make a recommendation to the State Board of Education to deny, suspend, or revoke approval of a cosmetology program, stating the basis for the recommendation in writing. A copy of the recommendation shall be provided to the local school system.
The local school system may file objections in response to the recommendation. The objections shall be filed with the State Board of Education within 30 days of receipt of the recommendation.
The State Board of Education shall make the final decision. A copy of the decision shall be promptly delivered or mailed to the local school system.
Reinstatement. The State Department of Education may reinstate approval of a cosmetology program for which approval has been revoked if the local school system:
Applies for reinstatement of approval in accordance with Regulation .01B of this chapter; and
Provides adequate evidence that the cosmetology program:
Has cured the deficiencies which were the basis for revocation; and
Meets the standards established in Regulations .02—.07 of this chapter.
